rangees.data: External shoulder rotation, glenohumeral joint coaptation
Average of 4 points of muscle belly

content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Shoulder at rest, arm along the body

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Palpate the main reliefs and landmarks of the scapula (spine, inferior angle, lateral border)

vues.title: Transverse View
objectifs: Appreciate the multipennate morphology of the infraspinatus
positionnement: Place the probe in transverse view (relative to infraspinatus fibers) on the scapular spine, just lateral to its center
To better locate and identify structures, slowly scan from superior to inferior to observe and differentiate the scapular spine, trapezius, infraspinatus, and supraspinatus
Move the probe slightly downward so that the scapular spine is just visible in the field

texte: The scapular spine and infraspinous fossa appear in the lower left portion of the image. The cortical bone not allowing ultrasound penetration, the muscle-bone interface is strongly hyperechoic
The lower trapezius, a hypoechoic band appearing at the top of the image, is the most superficial muscle
The infraspinatus, a large almost triangular hypoechoic area, occupies the entirety of the infraspinous fossa
One of the septa separating the superior head of the infraspinatus from the other heads appears as a hyperechoic line curved to the left

text: The infraspinatus muscle, located at the posterior aspect of the shoulder, is one of the 4 muscles belonging to the rotator cuff (along with the teres minor, subscapularis, and supraspinatus). This muscle maintains close relationships with the teres minor, both in terms of their location and more functional aspects.

The infraspinatus originates in the infraspinous fossa (scapula) and inserts, via a broad tendon, on the lateral facet of the greater tuberosity, just below the supraspinatus insertion. Although the gross anatomy of the infraspinatus is fairly well known, some important morphological concepts still lack consensus.

In the literature, when the pennation of the infraspinatus is described (it is often omitted), it is reported as either: multipennate, bipennate, compartmentalized, and/or fused with the teres minor [4][5][6][7][8]. However, a recent study [2] noted (in 100% of their 48 subjects) the unequivocal separation of the infraspinatus into 3 heads (superior, middle, and inferior). Each of these heads being clearly delimited by its own fascial envelope, but all being part of the same neuromuscular unit (although this aspect is subject to anatomical variability).

In ultrasonography, the different heads ('partitions') of the infraspinatus are well visible and clearly delimited: to avoid any confusion during structure identification, this concept must be well understood. There are 3 heads to the infraspinatus, each

content.subtitle: Pedagogy
text: The examination of the infraspinatus as described in this section is not part of the classic routine of ultrasonographic shoulder evaluation.
The techniques demonstrated are of more pedagogical interest (e.g., anatomy demonstration, practice of ultrasound equipment use) than clinical.
